There is the nominal burden of the actual net amount which, after all the trouble, is eventually extracted from them. In addition to that, there is the cost of collection to the State, and there is the cost of collection to the individual. My experience is that on the average, the cost of collection to the individual is considerably greater than the cost of collection to the State. I do not estimate the actual net cost to the State and to the individual of actually putting the income tax income into the possession of the State at less than between £600,000 and £700,000 per year. In addition to that, there is all the trouble, annoyance, complication and anxiety. The position which I think Deputy Law had in mind and which was the gravamen of his complaint was that it was the difference between paying for a taxicab and taking an ordinary jarvey. The average man will take twenty journeys in a taxi, knowing that he is going to know by an automatic process what he is going to have to pay, for the one journey that he would take with the feeling that he is going to have an argument and negotiation, and possibly a fight, at the end to decide what his obligation is.

There is very much of that atmosphere at the present moment in relation to income tax, and, quite apart from the question of changes that will have to be made eventually in it. anything that can be done to simplify the procedure is to the good. It is to be remembered, if what the Minister for Finance has said is true, that our income tax is on a rising grade, that the putting of income tax on the previous year, as distinct from the average of the three previous years, is a device for collecting more income tax. In other words, it is an attempt to get a greater yield of income tax. Whether that is going to be compensated by greater facilities will depend very largely on whether the methods used by the Income Tax Commissioners are methods which are directed for the convenience of the taxpayer.

There was during the last year a Departmental Income Tax Committee. Now, that Committee undoubtedly consisted of experts in the extraction of income tax. But it did not include, nor was it intended to include, apparently, the ordinary person who is an expert in having income tax extracted from him. What is wanted is an inquiry into income tax, not merely from the point of view of the revenue, but from the point of view of those from whom it is extracted. I believe that such a Committee could, after quiet consideration and co-operation, find much simpler methods of getting the vast bulk of the total income tax. For instance, you have this extraordinary case: There were £65,000 assessments under Schedule B for 1927-28, or whatever was the last available return. The total product was somewhere about £80,000. Now, if you divide one of these figures by the other, you will find what the actual individual assessment was. If you consider that that tax was upon the land, which is supposed to be the main producer of wealth in this country, and that the total amount which that tax could extract directly, at the closest point of production, was £80,000 out of 4½ millions, and that after you had extracted that, due to your system of taxation, in order to meet that primary producer who was originally in possession of practically all the wealth produced, you had to pay back to him. £2,600,000 in relief of his ordinary expenses, I think it will be admitted that that tax is shown to be utterly absurd and ridiculous as applied to the actual facts of this country.

I hope that when we come to closer quarters with the matter the Minister may consider very carefully whether “B” is worth collecting at all and whether, under some of the other Schedules, having regard to the enormous proportion of the total amount of income tax which is collected from very few people, the actual saving in raising the limit and excluding from that taxation a very large number of people who are now assessed unproductively the net yield, as distinct from the gross yield, would be increased and the widely distributed annoyance of some hundreds of thousands would be removed. There were 574,691 actual assessments made in the year 1926-7, to get an income of about £4,900,000. Now, if the Minister will work out the proportion of that which is paid by a very small number and the cost of collecting the amount of that from that very small number, he will find, in my opinion, that the net income from income tax will be largely increased by reducing the number of assessments from 574,000 to a very much smaller figure.

The second point I would like to raise, and frankly I am not in a very censorious mood—I do not approach Budget Debates in that spirit —is this: The Minister said that “In order to ascertain the real weight of our National Debt it is necessary to deduct from the gross figure of £23,517,000 already mentioned the amount of certain exchequer assets totalling £9,534,000, of which the following are the principal items.” I understand the contention there to be this: that this country, in so far as it had certain assets, definite assets, calculable assets, against this actual indebtedness, to that extent was in a better financial position. In other words, in taking the credit position of the country you had simply to consider the difference between total borrowing and the total assets. On that basis our broad general contention that the Free State has one of the smallest national debts in the world would not come out very well. Australia, New Zealand, and other places would be entitled to put up on that contention, against the money they have already borrowed, any figure which their Minister for Finance could show had been expended on these items.

Now if we turn to the actual assets which are laid down by the Minister for Finance it is necessary for us to enquire whether in fact they are assets. The fact that the Minister for Finance has seen that the money was spent in a particular way does not mean that they are assets. They are Exchequer assets; they are debts by the community to the Exchequer, but they are in no sense assets unless what was bought with them is worth what was paid. If for instance £1,000,000 was borrowed and was spent on the Fishery Department of the Minister opposite what would be its valuation in the mind and estimation of the House?

If you take any other case of expenditure which would be recklessly thrown away, no matter what amount it is, and no matter how definitely it has been segregated for the purpose, unless the actual asset which is bought with it is worth the money, it is not an asset but a debt. Now let us come to the consideration of some of these assets which the Minister for Finance certifies £9,534,000 was expended on. We will pass the Exchequer balance of £749,000. Advances to the Unemployment Fund, £881,000, is an asset, an Exchequer asset, but is it an asset in the sense of showing an existing realisable value in this State for the money which has been expended? What is it but an advance to pay moneys which have now been expended? It, some day or other, has to be raised out of this community, but it is not an asset. It is purely and simply a liability on the community, and the finance that would call that £881,000 an asset of the Free State, as distinct from a debt by the Free State to the Minister for Finance, is the sort of finance that we have been used to from the benches opposite.

The next item, and I do not propose to go through the whole lot of them, is £4,076,000 for the Shannon Fund. Is there in existence in Ireland at present a realisable asset of £4,076,000 to balance the £4,076,000 which has been spent on the Shannon? I would like to ask the Electricity Board that question. I think they know. I am quite sure the Minister for Fisheries would be unfairly treated if he were asked to express an opinion on that point. The actual work done and valued at £4,200,000 under the 1925 Act is not worth £4,200,000. That, regarded simply as a single issue, is insolvent.

The whole commercial value of the Shannon scheme to-day is dependent on the powers given to it under the 1927 Act to confiscate existing realisable values in electrical supplies, to break price standards held out as an inducement to the passing of that Act, to absorb income tax and rate values of existing and proposed electricity works and the monopoly value of the total ownership of retail electrical accessories and supplies. There is sunk in the Shannon scheme, in order to make it barely watertight, an amount of money which I estimate to be equal to the nominal amount it cost. If the Shannon scheme is, in the sense in which we use the term, ordinarily to be regarded as an asset, the income from the Shannon scheme must be prepared to pay the interest on sinking fund, not upon £4,200,000, but probably on a figure much more nearly approximating to £9,000,000 —this asset of £4,076,000 which is not able to cheapen electricity in the two principal centres upon which it depends for its life, Dublin and Cork. If this asset never existed, if not one single penny of this £4,076,000 had been expended Dublin to-day not merely could but would be getting its electricity cheaper. Because £4,076,000 has been spent upon this asset the price gradient, which has fallen in four or five years in Dublin from eightpence to fourpence and would in this year have fallen, in my opinion, to 3½d., and could in subsequent years, with development, have been driven lower, has been made fixed. We are told by the Electricity Supply Board, and I am not blaming them in any way—they have taken over certain powers; they have got to administer them— that because this £4,076,000 has been spent, because this asset has been created, Dublin must pay more for its electricity to-day and in future than if this scheme had never been initiated.

Turn to Cork. Take the estimated price of electricity delivered to the transformers outside Cork by the experts and by Siemens Schuckert. That price at the transformer outside Cork is higher than that current can be put on the low tension switch-board to-day with a steam plant in the City of Cork. Because this asset of £4,076,000 has been created electricity cannot be put on the switch-board in Cork and on the low tension supply system as cheaply as if this £4,076,000 asset never was brought into being. Yet it is one of the things which makes for the stability and credit of this country. It is one of the things that reduces the net national debt to say that this £4,076,000 has been spent.

Advances to the Unemployment Fund, a debt of £881,000—called an asset. The Shannon Fund, £4,076,000 of expenditure, which cannot cheapen the price according to the Shannon Board themselves and according to the experts in Dublin or Cork, also an asset. The Electricity Supply Board, £275,000, an asset. That asset is eventually going to be an asset of £2,500,000, and it means a liability to buy out the electricity supply in Cork and places like that in order that they may no longer function to show that with their steam plant they could generate current cheaper than an asset of £4,076,000 under the Shannon scheme. The Electricity Supply Board—a loss, and the fruitful mother, I think, of future losses, unless a much wiser system is used in its administration, unless it tries to do what, up to a point, it most certainly did not try to do to get behind it the public opinion of this country and the sympathy and support of consumers of electricity in this country to see that the best that can be made is made out of the expenditure of nine millions of money which is represented by the partial attempt at the first development of the electrification of the Free State.

The Road Fund, £640,000, is money which has been advanced, and frankly, I think, whether the Free State has been wise or not in the choice of the roads which it has chosen for the purpose of expending money, there is undoubtedly in this country an asset of actual practical value in the improvement which has been made in roads. Whether it is represented by all the money that has been spent, whether it is represented, by this £640,000, I personally am not in a position to say. It would be a matter for investigation, but that is the first item in this list of assets, apart from cash on hands, which anyone could possibly call a realisable asset. As to the Local Loan Fund of £1,081,000, here again it depends altogether on what was done with the money. Anyone who wanted to investigate the position of the Free State as a business concern, to make up its capital account, would have to go through these particular things and value the product of the expenditure of that money. Advances to the National City Bank made in connection with Guarantee Loans, £300,000, a capital asset! You move over a few pages and you find that £200,000 of that is being recovered. It is going into the hands of the Minister for Finance, and it immediately becomes income. What is written down here, £300,000, as a capital asset when £200,000 of the same kind of money comes into the possession of the Minister for Finance is expended as ordinary day to day expenditure; it is not put against abnormal expenditure, it is not put against contingencies, it is normal, ordinary income. Assets become income. As to that £300,000, has anybody valued the remainder of it? What has happened to it? It is guaranteed by the Government, it is money advanced, it is money which is calculated as an asset, it is money which, if it is lost, does not come back to the Government. That is what is called guaranteed by the Government. This is an asset. Does that contain the money which went into a glass bottle factory? Does that contain any of the money which went into another scheme which I do not want particularly to allude to at the moment?

Has any of it gone into the gramophone shares of which this Government is an unconscious possessor. £9,350,000 of assets! Let us see what they are again. £881,000 liability of the citizens of this State to the Minister for Finance, £4,076,000 to keep up the price of electricity in Dublin, £275,000, eventually to be £2,500,000, or any amount more which is required. The fruitful mother of further losses! An indefinite amount of £1,081,000 for local loans, £300,000 for guaranteed trades loans, which sometimes is income, sometimes is capital, and sometimes does not exist; and £580,000 for the purchase of creameries, a scheme which, up to the present, whatever the reason is, has not been able to get for the farmers who supply it with milk the same price for butter that could be obtained for the farmers that did not supply it at all; £580,000 of an asset for that. It may be worth something. Does the House seriously believe that financial statements of that kind should come from responsible Ministers for Finance?

It might be suggested that in making this statement one is giving the game away, one is destroying the shop window so carefully laid out by the Minister for Finance for the purpose of entangling the money birds later on. I might be tempted not to if it had that effect. I might be tempted when the Minister for Finance goes for his loans in spite of the organised activity of his colleagues to debase and degrade the credit of this State, to continue their policy of debasing and degrading the credit of this State, as they did through the mouth of the Minister for Justice, as they did through the mouth of the President, as they did through the mouth of the Minister for Finance himself, at the end of the last general election, when they were not sure that they would carry on, and when they let the National Loan fall one and a half points, when £7 10s. would have saved it, for polemical, political and other Party purposes. I hope that when the Minister for Finance does come for his loan he will get it, or his successor will get it, upon the sound credit of this Free State in spite of the damaged and degraded credit of the Cumann na nGaedheal Party.

They know to the contrary. Do they really believe for a single moment that there is any competent person concerned with the finances of this State who does not know what I have been now saying, who does not know that it is pure spoof to call a debt an asset and that it is pure spoof to call anything worth exactly what you paid for it?

What have the Irish banks said and done in this matter? Whether or not they have told the Minister for Finance, I cannot say, but they do know the value of those assets. They have taken the trouble to investigate the matter, and I am perfectly sure none of them is going to buy £181,000 as anything but a liability. The State will eventually produce it; but on the same basis you could wipe out the whole debt and say that we have no debt. This State has absorbed none of its borrowing powers in so far as it is capable of paying interest and sinking fund upon the total of its debts. That sort of finance will not redound to the credit of this country. It will not redound in any way to the benefit of this State in the rates which it will have to pay for money when it goes into the market to buy it. Impudence of that kind will not either deceive or conciliate those whose business it may be to find finance. The sooner the Minister for Finance and his colleagues wake up to the fact that they are not living in a sealed, a water-tight compartment, and that the day has passed when they could say, like Sir Oracle, “When I speak let no dog bark,” the better for the country. That day has passed, and the sooner they tell the truth in this and in other financial matters the better for themselves and the credit of the country.

In view of the fact that these figures are put down as assets, I would advise this House to disregard every figure they receive from the Minister for Finance which is not actually proved to demonstration, and audited by some separate authority over his head. It is utterly untrustworthy finance. It may be customary finance on the part of the Front Bench opposite, but it is a type of finance which ought to be very rapidly removed from the Front Bench of any Government which represents any part of Ireland.

Speaker.P: Deputy MacEntee indicated that in his opinion shrinkage of revenue was likely to continue in the future as in the past. He gave figures which, of course, I could not take down. I will examine them when I see them in print. So far as my examination of returns of stamp duties and death duties is concerned, I think that there is no indication at all of any substantial decline for several years in respect of them. In the case of stamp duties, there are certain factors which do not indicate any fall in prosperity, and, in fact, do not even necessarily indicate any decline in business, although they may cause a decline in yield. The prices of houses, for instance, have been falling, and one of the factors which has brought about that fall in prices of houses in Dublin— and there are quite considerable sales of houses in Dublin—has been the provision of more houses. If the housing policy of the Government were speeded up, I believe that the prices of houses would fall still further. Then we would have a decline in the yield of stamp duties. Then in certain dealings in stocks there might be a fall in revenue as a result of prices which would not indicate any likelihood of a decline in revenue generally. As a matter of fact, taking it year by year, there have been only inconsiderable fluctuations in the yield of stamp duties. To draw any inference from that in regard to the revenue position generally one would need to take even a longer period.

MainHeading.P: It may be that the Deputy was quoting the payment of stamp duty into the Exchequer, but in the case of any of these taxes some substantial fluctuation from year to year may take place because of the day of the week on which the financial year ends. There may be a substantial revenue, for instance, coming in on the last day or within a few days before the end of the year. Again, money may have been paid in stamps in a particular year and not have been paid into the Exchequer. The next year may be swollen unduly by the carry-over. I would need to look at the Deputy's figures in print before I could deal with them. Taking the actual collection for stamp duties in particular years, we had no substantial fluctuations up to the end of the year 1927. With regard to death duties, there are additional——

Speaker.P: May I take the liberty of directing the Minister's attention to the fact that in 1925-26 the revenue from stamp duties was £508,000? The position really so far as those two particular matters of estate duty or death duties taken as a whole and stamps are concerned is that there is nothing at all so far to indicate any shrinkage. I think the period is too short to gather anything from these figures. In respect of certain items the estate duty figure would indicate an improvement, but you cannot in such a short period draw any conclusions of value from these figures. You would need to have the figures for four or five years more before any conclusions of value could be come to. But there is no indication at all of any shrinkage. While there is no indication yet of any big improvement the indications are of a gradual, if slow, improvement. With regard to the burden of taxation about which the Deputy spoke and about the figure of national income, I should say that the figures of national income are of very little value except perhaps for showing movements in certain condition.

If the figure of national income is calculated it will be found that there are elements of guesses in every aspect of the calculation, and the variations can be extremely wide. One economist might take a set of existing circumstances as we find them here, so far as they are shown statistically, and calculate the national income at £50,000,000. Another statistician might take the same set of figures and by making different allowances calculate the national income at £150,000,000. There would be very little value in either of them except for the purpose of making calculations from time to time to try to assess what is the drift or movement. In any case, no figure of national income for the Saorstat has been calculated, and if we had a figure of national income it would not be of any value in relation to the levying of taxation. The Deputy has himself indicated that no less important than the amount of the taxation is the use to which the taxation is put. In fact, towards the end of his remarks he talked about relieving people by increasing social services or by less taxation. I will not say that those are his exact words. But he indicated that increasing expenditure of a particular type was the equivalent of reduced taxation. It would be possible for people to be taxed up to 98 per cent. of the national income for the purpose of distributing that income out again to the people in some way that is thought more equitable.

You can draw no conclusion as to taxable capacity from any calculations as to national income without taking into account what is being done with the money raised from taxation and what services the people are getting. The whole question of taxation really comes down to a question of national services, the need for them, and, so far as those services do not actually stimulate production, where the burden can be borne by the producer, because it may well be that the most desirable social services are such as, in the particular state of industry in a country production cannot bear. Looking at the matter from a different angle to my friend, Deputy Byrne, I do think that any remarks which purport to show that there is a particular national income here and that a particular rate of taxation is imposed because the national income is at that figure, are of really no value at all.

The falling proportion of direct taxation was referred to by Deputy MacEntee. That was mainly due to the fact that there were exceptional items, chiefly arrears of income tax, in the way of taxation collected in the earlier years, and also to the fact that our income tax was at an extremely high rate during the first year or two after the setting up of the Saorstát. Deputy Anthony asked for an allowance of one-sixth where an income was less than £208 a year. If I understood the Deputy rightly, I do not think that it would be possible to give an allowance at the rate of one-sixth when an income is under £208, and not to give it over that. If the Deputy's idea was simply to benefit a particular class of people, those who were unmarried and who had incomes at that rate, I do not think that that is the most desirable way of using up any margin which we might have at any time. I think that increased allowances for children should be really the first thing that we should do in connection with increased allowances to income tax payers, and if we are giving increased allowances I think that you cannot confine such allowances to those who are under that particular income. I think that you would have to give it on that particular range of income, and give it to anybody. While the income tax code is very complicated, the giving of reliefs, in the way in which I understand Deputy Anthony suggests, would bring in an additional element of complication.

The same thing really arises with respect to a child born during the year. I think that the present arrangement applies at both ends of the period during which the parents are entitled to relief from taxation. Complications would arise in making supplementary claims if we altered the present arrangement. Deputy Anthony also suggested that the changes proposed should be applied this year. For administrative purposes that is impossible, and it would cause delay in collection.

Deputy Shaw referred to the Report of the Committee which has been considering the Betting Act and its suggestion as to race-course betting being relieved of tax. I have not had time to consider that recommendation. I have not considered since last year the conditions of the race-course executives. My view was that, as the whole matter of the Betting Act was being examined by a Committee, it was just as well to defer any reconsideration of the position until we had the report of that Committee and could deal with the whole matter at once. I am not at all influenced by anything that was said with reference to the operations of the Betting Tax in England. I was of the opinion from the beginning that the Betting Tax could not be made to work satisfactorily unless there were licences for the betting shops there in the same way as there are licences here. From the first announcement of the conditions under which the tax was applied in England I, and anybody who examined the matter here, were of the opinion that it would inevitably fail.

I think that the tax is quite a different proposition here. I have no grounds yet for believing that the condition of Irish racing would be put right by a remission of the Betting Tax on courses. I think that the cause of the trouble is, perhaps, deeper than the Betting Tax, and I think that Deputy Shaw himself has shown a realisation of that fact. He has indicated that in his view there is a good deal more wrong than the burden that is imposed by the Betting Tax. I had hopes that before this the Committee which has been appointed, representing the Turf Club and other people interested, would have succeeded in installing the totalisator. I indicated to that Committee that I was willing to issue a licence to them and, if necessary, to come to the Dáil for a re-enactment, as a permanent Act, of the clauses of the Betting Act which authorise the totalisator. The Committee, apparently, has not been able to make up its mind as to what type of totalisator is to be used, and also as, to other matters in connection with it. Nothing, at all events, has been done. People who favoured the totalisator always suggested to me that a tremendous improvement in the attendance at race meetings would follow the inauguration of the totalisator here. There have been people who suggested—I do not think that Deputy Shaw was one of them—that the totalisator should have a monopoly of betting. I stated always that I would not agree to that. I do not think that if the totalisator is to be set up and if taxation is to be taken. off it it would be possible to leave the bookmaker free of tax. It is very difficult to consider this single point of the tax on bets on race-courses separately from the whole position of Irish racing.

It is difficult to consider that separately from the totalisator. If the totalisator is going to do good in regard to attendances at race meetings, then the prospects of the totalisator are going to be injured if it is going to pay two-and-a-half per cent. tax and the bookmaker, competing with it, is to pay no tax, and if we are not going to get any tax from the totalisator I would have to reconsider the matter. In any case, I do not want to be put in the position of yielding to appeals to relieve the bookmaker and then to be told that because the bookmaker has been relieved no tax can be imposed on the totalisator. Generally, I think that the whole matter requires a little bit of consideration. Prior to other Budgets representations were made to me by people in touch with the condition of the race-course executives. They have not done so this year, and, as I say, I have not looked into that matter because I was awaiting the result of the deliberations of the Committee on the Betting Act.

Deputy Lemass made a suggestion that, instead of calculating the amount that was likely to be saved during a particular year and deducting it from the total to be found by taxation for that year, we should carry over whatever balance there might be towards the relief of the next year. That suggestion is quite all right. I think that probably at some time the matter could be arranged in that way, but in any case no excessive amount is being allowed against over-estimation. I am quite satisfied that the amount that has been put down could be realised, and the only advantage that Deputy Lemass's suggested method would have would be that it would prevent an inflated figure being used. It has that to recommend it. He seemed to suggest that it should not be taken into account at all but that any figure that could be saved should simply go to the reduction of debt.

That is done in Great Britain, but the position here is that we have proportionately an enormously greater sinking fund provision. The arrangements that were made in connection with the issue of the National Loan secured that we pay ample sums towards the extinction of debt in a year, and it would be really burdening the people unduly if we used such realisable surplus as might be obtained in any particular year, as will inevitably arise in the system of estimation which exists, for the further extinction of debt.

With regard to more capital expenditure, the real difficulty is to find schemes which arc either fully economic or nearly so. The drainage schemes to which Deputy Lemass referred will, in most cases, be anything from 50 to 90 per cent. uneconomic. There is absolutely no doubt that all the good drainage schemes have been done, and that whatever remains is the bad and the middling drainage schemes, possibly schemes which should never be undertaken. We hear suggestions that drainage should be carried out in certain cases. It would really be better to spend the money on almost anything than to carry out some drainage schemes, because there would be no return from the capital sunk in them. While they might not be as bad as works that were carried out in famine times under the British administration, such as digging a hole and filling it in, they would be very nearly as bad, although one might call them drainage schemes and put a certain face on it. They would not be much better than the work carried out in the famine days. While a certain amount of drainage has been done, most of it is borderline work. Most of the work done under the Drainage Act involves such a loss, if we take into account the cost of carrying out the work and the benefits accruing to the lands drained, that it is quite doubtful whether it should be done or not. Drainage work is done partly as an economic work and partly as a relief scheme which gives some employment in the neighbourhood. I do not think that very great capital sums could be wisely spent on schemes like that.

In regard to reclamation, the same would apply. No reasonable return would be obtained from expenditure on such schemes. Some little work has been done in Connemara, and it may be possible to do more, simply to deal with the peculiar problem there. You cannot really satisfactorily migrate the people there for any great distance, and one way to relieve their condition may be found in schemes of reclamation, but it is not the sort of work for which we should borrow money, nor should we really borrow money for drainage, because any drainage that is likely to be done is so far from economic as not to justify it.

Forestry really represents a half economic work. I have so far treated money spent on the purchase of land and. on cultural work in connection with forestry as money that might be equally divided between normal and abnormal expenditure. I think probably that on the best calculation we can make, the forest, when it grows, will be worth about half the money spent on it. Perhaps forestry is the best of these schemes. So far as sewerage and water schemes are concerned, the Local Loans Fund has been open for these works for some considerable time, and any money that will be required will be advanced and paid back in due course by the local authorities. Schemes like the Shannon scheme are difficult to find. If we could get a scheme of construction like the Shannon scheme, we might spend £50,000,000, and might borrow that sum for it. No loss of credit or no wrong financing would be involved, but so far the position has been that such schemes are not forthcoming.

With regard to the Trade Loans Act, to which I think Deputy Lemass referred, we could lose an immense amount of money in connection with the encouragement of industry if we followed the lines laid down by Deputy Lemass. The conclusion I have come to, from my experience of the Trade Loans Act, is not that we have too many fences, but, if anything, that we have too few fences. If we tried to carry on along the lines Deputy Lemass suggested, of looking for enterprising young fellows with no capital, but with splendid ideas, and handed them out money to make their own and the country's fortune, it would be like pouring money into a sieve. People who might do well in handling their own money or the money of their immediate friends or relatives, would deal with State money with a very lavish hand. I am perfectly convinced that no good results could follow from the procedure which Deputy Lemass seems to suggest, but there would be simply a wholesale waste of the money of the tax-payers, who can ill afford to have it wasted. I think it would be altogether wrong that for any industry, such as might call for assistance, the State should supply the working capital.

Whatever chance the industry has otherwise, it is practically sure to be mismanaged if the State really takes all the risks, which is what Deputy Lemass's scheme would amount to. If you try to save the State money by having all the Civil Service checks and delays, then you cannot run the thing as an industry, and it will fail for another reason. I think that along the lines of supplying capital there is nothing really that would be very effective that can be done by the State. What I indicated last night was, not that nothing was to be done for industry, or that the industrial situation was to be despaired of, but simply that so far as industry could be helped that help must be more by a tariff or some sort of help along other lines and not the finding of capital. The way to help industry was to make pretty sure that those who invested capital would, if they worked the industry right, be able to make a profit, and if that situation was created, sufficient capital would beforthcoming.

Deputy Law asked that each taxpayer should be in the position of being easily able to know how much he had to pay, and he cited a case where relief should have been given and could not be obtained because the claim had not been put in in time—that it was refused really for a technical reason. I should like to look further into the sort of case he cited, but, generally speaking, we are trying to simplify the income tax code. It is a big work, which we have not had sufficient staff to touch until this year, but we hope that, making a beginning this year, we will be able to continue the work of simplification and to get as near as possible to having every taxpayer able to understand his liability and the reliefs to which he is entitled, and so know exactly what he has to pay. I should like to point out to Deputy Law in that connection that all the claims for special relief for hard cases, and all that sort of thing, all tend to make the code more complex, and while, on the one hand, we have people calling for simplification, we also have other people, without knowing it, working against simplification and trying to get all sorts of new special reliefs to cover all sorts of hard cases. I think if we are working for simplification we must make up our minds that we cannot multiply all sorts of reliefs or special provisions.

With regard to the treatment of visitors, so far as the American is concerned, if he is resident here he has only to pay tax on remittances, on practically the money he brings and spends here. I do not think that he can ever be in any doubt. I think it can always be made clear to him that he can easily know exactly what he will have to pay in taxation. Of course he would not, if he only came and took a furnished house for one year, be liable to tax at all. He would only be liable to tax if he took an unfurnished house and furnished it and came a number of years in succession. With regard to the visitor from England, I think the position now is fairly simple. If he lives anywhere near London, and can visit the conjoint office, or is willing to employ an agent to visit it, what will really happen is that he will have to sign a form that he will pay his income tax to the British authorities and that we will get our share from the conjoint office, and he practically will not have to deal with us at all. So far as the man is concerned who cannot, through an agent or personally, visit the conjoint office, the position is still relatively simple. I do not know whether it would be possible to give any further facilities or not. The great majority of people who take houses here are people who either have a banking account with banks that do income tax business and can act for them at the conjoint office, or people who might go to the conjoint office themselves. Certainly, they have the minimum of trouble, because already having furnished returns to the British authorities and given the necessary particulars, when they sign, the requisite form will be supplied at the conjoint office to our. representative there and no difficulties will arise. If the conjoint office is not brought into it, of course they will have to make a duplicate return, but that would be practically the only additional trouble they will have.

Speaker.P: Do I understand that form is actually in existence or is only proposed?
They will have some little correspondence. It is not just simply signing one form, but it is the minimum of trouble.
Is the form actually in use at present?

Yes. Deputy Derrig suggested that if it were not possible to de-rate, an additional amount should be given by way of agricultural grant. My feeling even. about increasing the agricultural grant is that some further examination of the position of local government should be undertaken. It was, perhaps, all right to give a second £600,000 to councils for the relief of agricultural rates and leave the position as it was before. But if another substantial sum were to be given, as big or bigger than that, as I suppose some people would ask, I think that. one of the results of doing it would be that we would have a decrease in. the rates the year the grant was given, or the year after, and then we would have the rates creeping up again to the old figure. My own position is that I would not be inclined to give any more money to-the local authorities from the Exchequer for the relief of rates until we had examined further the machinery of local government.
Does the Minister insinuate that local authorities are not to be trusted?

I think they are to be trusted to make good any reduction in the rates that might result from an increase from the State grant after a year or so. As I gather, the main burden of criticism was that there was no justification for thinking that the economic slump under which we have suffered has actually come to an end. Then there was the criticism that we were not announcing large schemes of public works. I am satisfied that there has been some improvement, and that there is every prospect of that improvement continuing. I am not satisfied that we can deal with the unemployment situation by rushing into big public works which are uneconomic. I think that if we keep burdens and expenditure down, when that, expenditure is not fully economic, that in that, way we are helping to relieve unemployment, because we are giving the private employer, who must always be by far the greatest employer in the country, an opportunity to do his work more satisfactorily.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Lemass, I think it was, suggested that we should cut our normal figure for the Army from one and a half million to one million. My view is that the time is past, and the point has been passed, for arbitrary cuts in connection with the Army. I think the question of Army expenditure has now to be approached from a different angle, As long as it was very high we could say: “This is a figure which we cannot possibly afford; we do not care what sort of an Army may be necessary; we are not going to pay so much for it.” But it is now cut down to one-and-a-half millions, and my view is that we must look at what can be done by way of creating a defence force within that limit, and, that having seen what sort of a defence force can be created for that, we must then see whether it is a defence force that can in any way be reduced. We must see, as we build up a new type of defence force, whether it can be carried on under one-and-a-half millions or not. If it can be carried on under one-and-a-half millions well and good. But if it cannot, I would be prepared to take the position that I would be ready to spend a million and a half upon it. While I have not the fears that Deputies on the other side have about aggression from outside which was likely to injure this country, apart altogether from any question of internal disturbance or politics, and assuming that that is quite out of the question, and that anything at all that may arise in that way is a matter that may be dealt with by the police, I am satisfied that for the security of the country and for the preservation of the rights of the people, and to prevent those rights being ignored and the country's wishes and interests being ignored by outsiders, on some future occasion, we must have an army here which would be a formidable organ of defence in case the country was subject to aggression.

For my part, I feel we can afford a million-and-a-half, if so much is necessary, for the creation and maintenance of such an instrument, and we are now gradually trying to evolve plan for building up a different type of army from what we had I indicated some years ago that the days of the standing army, except for some small corps or small number of units, were over, and that we must aim at the creation of a militia or territorial force which would be very much greater in numbers than any standing army that could be maintained. I do not know whether less will do for the Army than is in the Estimates this year or not, but I am satisfied you cannot get big cuts such as you had before.

I do not believe any reduction can be made in the police Vote in future. Even if there was a reduction in numbers the men will be longer in the force; they are still young, and they are not at anything like the top of their incremental scale, and their increments will counterbalance any saving that may be got by a falling off in numbers. Generally, so far as expenditure may be reduced in the future, it has got to be reduced by a policy of scraping out something that can be done without, although it may be good, or when some service dies or becomes smaller, which would normally be replaced by a new one, not replacing it. There is no sort of easy way by which we can expend all sorts of new sums on social services and find the money without additional taxation. If we are to find money for new social services which Deputies want, or hint at, then, in practice, it will be found that the money will have to come out of extra taxation. In all these cases it is a question of striking the best balance we can. I am satisfied with this generally, and by way of summing up again, I may say that abnormal items have practically disappeared from our revenue, that there is no reduction at all, looking over the whole field, that we are going to suffer from falling revenue. We have, on the other hand, abnormal items gradually falling out of our expenditure side, and we are now in the position that we have something like normal services and something like normal revenue, and that while it will be possible, I hope, to get some further reduction in expenditure, that reduction will not be such as will enable big new schemes of social services to be undertaken otherwise than by the imposition of fresh taxation.
